posts.post_content:
According to the explanation given with the banning, this was the card in storm decks that was the easiest to ban which allowed "frequent" 3rd turn wins, which is a no-no in modern. They didn't want to completely invalidate storm decks, so they gave it a limp instead.  
  
The question is what will storm fill that gaping 4 card hole with after the banning? and how many people will give up on the deck because of the loss in speed?

posts.post_content:
Want to make people hate you in EDH?  
  
All right, here goes.  
  
You're playing [Scion of the Ur-Dragon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Scion of the Ur-Dragon). Lucky you, you have the ![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol)![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol)![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol)![Red](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=R&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol) to play your Scion. By some small act of god, your general survives his first turn out and it's now your turn, he's ready to swing, and that one pesky opponent doesn't have a flier out.  
  
So you decide to murder the hell out of him. Pay 2 to copy [Dragon Tyrant](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dragon Tyrant), then your remaining 3 mana to cast this, pump the Tyrant'd Scion five times with its firebreathing, and then proceed to deliver fatal commander damage in one shot.
posts.html:
Want to make people hate you in EDH?

All right, here goes.

You're playing Scion of the Ur-Dragon. Lucky you, you have the to play your Scion. By some small act of god, your general survives his first turn out and it's now your turn, he's ready to swing, and that one pesky opponent doesn't have a flier out.

So you decide to murder the hell out of him. Pay 2 to copy Dragon Tyrant, then your remaining 3 mana to cast this, pump the Tyrant'd Scion five times with its firebreathing, and then proceed to deliver fatal commander damage in one shot.
